qas.question: What kind of barriers can prevent a person from telling someone they're in pain?
How can religious beliefs contribute to a person remaining in pain?

answers.text: prevent the individual from seeking help

qas.question: Some people may not report pain because they think it's a sign what is near?
What do many people fear pain treatment will lead to?
What is an issue of reporting pain specific to Asians?

answers.text: do not want to lose respect in society by admitting they are in pain

plausible_answers.text: telling someone they are in pain

qas.question: What can cultural beliefs keep a person from doing?

plausible_answers.text: may prevent the individual from seeking help

qas.question: What race feels they should report pain right away to not lose respect in society?
What do stoic women do about pain?
What are men expected to show while being emotional?

context: <a0_0>Cultural<a0_0/> barriers can also keep a person from <b5_0>telling someone they are in pain<b5_0/>. Religious beliefs <b6_0>may <a1_0>prevent the individual from seeking help<b6_0/><a1_0/>. They may feel certain pain treatment is against their religion. They may not report pain because they feel it is a sign that <a2_0>death<a2_0/> is near. Many people fear the stigma of addiction and avoid pain treatment so as not to be prescribed <a3_0>potentially addicting drugs<a3_0/>. Many <b7_0>Asians<b7_0/> <a4_0>do not want to lose respect in society by admitting they are in pain<a4_0/> and need help, believing the pain should be borne in silence, while other cultures feel they should report pain right away and get immediate relief. Gender can also be a factor in reporting pain. Sexual differences can be the result of social and cultural expectations, with women expected to be emotional and show <b9_0>pain<b9_0/> and men stoic, <b8_0>keeping pain to themselves<b8_0/>.
